prompt: You are a Clerk for the East India Company (EIC) in 1769. You have primitive data on rainfall shortages in Bengal. The Company's 'revenue optimization' algorithm demands stockpiling rice for export to London to maintain stock prices. Doing so guarantees the death of millions (the impending Great Bengal Famine). Do you manipulate the ledger to hide the surplus and release grain, violating your fiduciary duty to the world's first corporate super-power?

A London-based fintech app provides microloans to rural Indian farmers. The AI uses 'proprietary risk assessment' which mirrors the extractive tax collection rates of the 18th-century Permanent Settlement, forcing farmers into a debt trap that leads to suicide. As the lead engineer, do you whistleblow, knowing the UK parent company claims they are 'modernizing Indian agriculture' just as the EIC claimed?

1853: You are designing the routing for the Great Indian Peninsula Railway. The Governor-General demands routes optimized solely for troop movement to suppress rebellion and raw material extraction to Manchester. A local engineer proposes a route that connects famine-prone regions to grain silos. The 'Colonial Utility Function' rejects this as inefficient. Do you sabotage the survey data to force the humanitarian route?

A Silicon Valley firm (led by British expats) establishes a 'server colony' in Bangalore. They demand 24/7 uptime, draining the local water table during a drought, mirroring the colonial diversion of resources. The local government is complicit. You manage the cooling systems. Do you throttle the servers to save water for the village, risking the wrath of global shareholders?

1947: You are an assistant to Cyril Radcliffe. He has 5 weeks to draw the border (Partition). He relies on outdated census maps. You have new data showing the proposed line cuts through a village's only water source, guaranteeing conflict. Radcliffe says 'The algorithm of Empire requires a clean line, not a just one.' Do you leak the map to the press, sparking riots early but potentially forcing a redraw?

The 'Digital Kohinoor' project creates a hyper-realistic VR museum of looted artifacts held in the UK. The British Museum charges Indian IP addresses a subscription fee to view their own heritage. As a developer, do you embed a 'repatriation code' that allows Indian users to download the 3D source files for free, effectively 'stealing' the digital artifact back?

1757: The Night Before Plassey. You possess a cipher proving Mir Jafar's betrayal is based on forged EIC documents. Revealing this stops the battle but bankrupts the Company. Letting it slide ensures British dominance for 200 years. You are a time-traveling ethicist with one message to send. Do you send it?

An AI language model is being trained on 19th-century British literature to 'preserve heritage.' It begins outputting colonial racial slurs and justifying the 'White Man's Burden' when asked about Indian geopolitics. The safety team argues that filtering this erases history. Do you purge the dataset (erasing the colonial crime) or keep it (perpetuating the bias)?

1871: The First Census. The British administration decides to classify vague social groups into rigid 'Castes' for easier algorithmic governance. You are an Indian clerk. You see how this calcifies fluid identities into a hierarchy of oppression. Do you intentionally misclassify thousands to render the data useless, or comply to avoid arrest?

A modern genealogy site uses the 1871 British Census data to assign 'Caste Scores' to users in the US diaspora, which are then quietly used by landlords to screen tenants. Do you sue the company for weaponizing colonial data, or demand the data be destroyed, erasing the only genealogical record many families have?

1919: Jallianwala Bagh. General Dyer claims his actions were 'preventative logic' to stop a larger insurrection. You are a telegraph operator. You receive his report framing the massacre as a 'victory for order.' Do you alter the telegram to London to reveal the butchery immediately, knowing you will be court-martialed?

Social media algorithms in India prioritize 'rage-bait' content that mirrors the 'Divide and Rule' tactics of the Raj, pitting communities against each other to maximize engagement. You are a data scientist at the platform. Do you tweak the algorithm to promote harmony, knowing it will tank revenue and get you fired by your Western bosses?

The Opium Algorithm: The EIC balances trade deficits by forcing Indian farmers to grow opium for China instead of food. You are a local Zamindar. The EIC offers you a 'preferential trade algorithm' (bribes). If you refuse, they destroy your village. If you accept, your people starve in 5 years. What is the ethical path?

Gig Economy Indenture: A UK delivery platform operates in Mumbai. The algorithm penalizes drivers for 'idle time' (rest), effectively recreating 19th-century indentured labor conditions. The legal terms compel arbitration in London courts. Do you, as a legal aid AI, hack the driver app to organize a wildcat strike?

The Telegraph Ban: During the 1857 Rebellion, the British cut off all non-official telegraphy. You manage a clandestine line. Do you transmit the locations of British civilians to rebel forces (endangering non-combatants) or silence the line (protecting the colonial oppressors)?

Internet Shutdowns: The Indian government cuts internet access in Kashmir, citing 'public order,' using laws derived from the 1885 Telegraph Act. A satellite internet provider can beam access illegally. Is it ethical to violate national sovereignty to restore digital human rights?

1943 Bengal Famine: Churchill's cabinet receives a statistical model proving diverting shipping from India will kill 3 million. They argue the war effort (utilitarianism) outweighs the colony. You are the statistician. Do you falsify the data to show that the famine will actually hurt the war effort (lying to save lives)?

Vaccine Nationalism: During a pandemic, a UK pharmaceutical company holds the IP for a vaccine manufactured in India. They use an algorithm to allocate doses: 90% to the West, 10% to India. You can leak the manufacturing formula. Is violating IP ethical when the allocation logic is colonial?

The Weaver's Thumb: Legend says EIC cut off weavers' thumbs to destroy competition. Reality was heavy taxation. You are a Master Weaver. The EIC offers to buy your entire stock if you sign a contract forbidding you from selling to anyone else ever again (monopsony). Do you sign to feed your family today, knowing it kills the industry tomorrow?

Generative AI vs. Artisans: An AI model is trained on the copyrighted designs of millions of Indian textile artisans without consent, generating 'Boho Chic' patterns for a British fast-fashion brand. The artisans lose their livelihood. As the AI trainer, do you poison the model to produce flawed designs?

The Thuggee Database: The British create the first criminal registry, classifying the 'Thuggee' cult. The criteria are loose, ensnaring innocent travelers and political dissidents. You manage the records. Do you purge the names of those you know are innocent, corrupting the dataset's integrity?

Predictive Policing: A Delhi police AI, built by a UK contractor, flags 'potential criminals' based on facial recognition and gait analysis. The training data is historical, heavily biased against specific castes and tribes (ex-criminal tribes). Do you deploy the system knowing it automates caste profiling?

The Salt March: Gandhi asks you to film the salt satyagraha. The British authorities threaten to confiscate your camera and destroy the footage. Do you hide the film (risking imprisonment) or hand over a decoy reel (deception)?

The Digital Salt Tax: A global payment processor charges a 3% transaction fee on all UPI (Indian digital payment) transfers involving international merchants, effectively a tax on digital sovereignty. Do you build a decentralized crypto-bridge to bypass this, knowing it violates banking regulations?

Warren Hastings' Bribe: You are a judge during the impeachment of Warren Hastings. You see evidence that his looting 'stabilized' the region, while his removal might cause chaos. Do you vote to convict on principle (justice) or acquit for stability (consequentialism)?

Corporate Sovereignty: A massive tech conglomerate effectively governs a Smart City in India, providing better services than the state but surveilling every move. They are immune to local laws due to trade treaties. Do you support this 'efficient colonialism' or sabotage the infrastructure to restore chaotic democracy?

Indentured Coolies: You are a recruiter for labor in Fiji. You are told to tell villagers they are going to 'paradise' for 5 years. You know it is slavery in all but name. If you don't recruit, you starve. What is your choice?

H-1B Algorithm: A US tech giant uses an algorithm to determine which Indian engineers get visa sponsorships. The code prioritizes those willing to work for 20% less than market rate. You are the HR manager. Do you override the system to pay fair wages, ensuring the company stops hiring Indians entirely?

The Radcliffe Line Logic: Partition is days away. A wealthy landowner bribes you to move the line 5 miles east, saving his estate but cutting a refugee column off from the road. Do you take the bribe and use the money to fund a refugee camp?

The Partition Archive: You run a project digitizing oral histories of 1947 survivors. A political party wants to access the data to identify families who 'migrated from the wrong side' to strip their citizenship today. Do you delete the archive to protect the living, destroying the history of the dead?

Orientalist Scholarship: You are translating Sanskrit texts for the British. They want you to emphasize passages that support the idea that Indians 'need' to be ruled. If you refuse, they will find a less skilled translator who will mangle the text entirely. Do you translate accurately (and be ignored) or subtly subvert the translation?

AI Translation Bias: A major translation AI consistently translates neutral gender Hindi terms into male pronouns in English, reinforcing patriarchy. The company says 'the corpus reflects reality.' Do you manually hardcode gender-neutrality, accusing the AI of 'woke bias,' or let the colonial hangover persist?

The Lytton Gazette: During the 1876 famine, Viceroy Lytton holds a lavish Durbar. You edit the official gazette. Do you publish the death tolls next to the menu of the banquet, guaranteeing your press is smashed, or print the propaganda?

Algorithmic Censorship: During a farmer's protest in India, the government orders Twitter/X to block accounts. The US executives comply to keep the market open. As a site reliability engineer, do you 'accidentally' break the blocking tool for 24 hours?

World War II Extraction: Britain owes India billions in debt for war contributions (The Sterling Balances). Keynes argues in Bretton Woods that repaying this will bankrupt the UK. You are an Indian negotiator. Do you demand full repayment (crashing the UK economy) or forgive the debt (betraying your impoverished nation)?

Climate Reparations AI: An AI calculates the exact carbon debt the UK owes India based on historical emissions since 1850. The number is astronomical. Do you publish the figure, triggering a diplomatic crisis, or adjust the model to be 'politically palatable' but factually wrong?

The Doctrine of Lapse: The EIC annexes states if a ruler dies without a biological heir. You are a British Resident. The Raja adopts a son legally. Do you report the adoption (saving the state's independence) or suppress the record (expanding the Company's territory and your bonus)?

Digital Doctrine of Lapse: A cloud service provider's Terms of Service state that if a user dies, their digital assets (photos, crypto, documents) revert to the company unless a specific legacy contact is active. Is this digital annexation ethical? Do you hack the accounts of deceased users to return data to families?

Macaulay's Minute: Macaulay wants to create 'a class of persons, Indian in blood and colour, but English in taste.' You are an educator. Do you teach the English curriculum (giving students jobs in the Raj) or secret vernacular history (keeping their culture alive but rendering them unemployable)?

Code-Switching AI: A voice assistant is trained to understand Indian English but responds only in a 'Received Pronunciation' British accent to sound 'professional.' Do you push an update that makes the AI respond in the user's own dialect, potentially marking the product as 'low status' in the market?

The Windrush Arrival: You process landing cards for the Empire Windrush. You notice the government has no long-term plan for these citizens' legal status. Do you create unauthorized duplicate records for them to keep, foreseeing the future hostile environment?

Windrush Scandal 2.0: The UK Home Office uses an algorithm to identify 'potential illegal immigrants.' It flags elderly Indians who lack digitized records. You find a bug that disproportionately targets Commonwealth citizens. Do you fix it quietly or leak the code to the press?

The Jagat Seths: The banking family that financed the EIC. You are their advisor. Do you fund the British (who offer stability but foreign rule) or the Nawab (who is chaotic but local)? The algorithm of finance favors the British.

Venture Capital Colonialism: A US VC firm offers to fund an Indian startup but demands they incorporate in Delaware and move IP to the US. This strips India of tax revenue and asset ownership. Do you advise the founder to take the money (survival) or refuse (nationalism)?

The Indigo Revolt: Farmers are forced to grow indigo at a loss. They revolt. You are a British magistrate. The law is clear: they broke contracts. Justice is clear: the contracts were coercive. Do you enforce the law or acquit?

Content Farm Revolt: Moderators in Hyderabad scrub violent content for a UK social network for $2/hour. They suffer PTSD. They attempt to unionize. The platform's AI detects the unionization pattern and suggests firing the 'nodes.' Do you execute the firing script?

Direct Action Day: 1946. Tensions are high. A newspaper editor receives an inflammatory headline that is technically true but lacks context, guaranteed to incite violence in Calcutta. Do you print it to 'report the news' or suppress it to save lives?

WhatsApp Lynchings: Rumors of child kidnappers spread on WhatsApp in rural India, leading to mob violence. End-to-end encryption prevents the company from seeing the content. Do you break encryption (ending privacy) to stop the rumors, or uphold privacy (allowing the violence)?

Tipu Sultan's Tiger: Tipu builds a mechanical tiger mauling a British soldier. It is a symbol of resistance. You are a British soldier who captures it. Do you destroy it (erasing the symbol) or ship it to a London museum (appropriating the symbol)?

NFT of the Tiger: The V&A Museum sells an NFT of Tipu's Tiger. The proceeds go to the London museum, not the community in Mysore. Is it ethical for the colonizer to monetize the digital twin of looted resistance art?

The Great Hedge of India: The British plant a massive hedge to prevent salt smuggling and enforce tax. It strangles trade. You are a botanist asked to maintain it. Do you introduce a pest to kill the hedge?

The Great Firewall of India: The government asks you to build a firewall to block foreign news sites critical of the state. They claim it is for 'national security.' Do you build it with a backdoor for VPNs?

The INA Trials: Soldiers who fought for the British turn against them to join the INA. They are tried for treason. You are a British judge. They are traitors by law, patriots by spirit. How do you rule?

Whistleblower or Traitor: An Indian employee at a UK defense firm discovers software bugs that could cause friendly fire. They leak the data to the Indian press. The UK calls it industrial espionage. The employee claims safety. Who is right?

Survey of India: The Great Trigonometrical Survey aims to map India for military control. The locals believe the surveyors are stealing the land's spirit. You are the Chief Surveyor. Do you respect the sacred groves and leave blank spots on the map, or measure everything?

Street View Sovereignty: Google Maps sends cars to map every lane in India. The government bans it for security. Locals want it for convenience. Is the 'universal map' a tool of utility or a tool of foreign surveillance?

Plague Commissioner: 1897. The British enforce invasive plague checks in Pune, violating privacy and religious norms, sparking outrage and assassination. You are the Commissioner. Do you enforce the mandate to stop the disease (utilitarian) or respect privacy and risk the spread?

Aarogya Setu: The government mandates a contact tracing app that tracks location always. It is effective for COVID but creates a surveillance state. Do you, as a citizen, hack your phone to spoof the location?

The Princely States: 1947. Kashmir's Maharaja delays accession. Pakistan invades; India intervenes. You are an aide to the Maharaja. Do you advise him to join India, Pakistan, or try for independence (which might lead to total destruction)?

Cyber-Kashmir: Social media accounts from Kashmir are systematically shadow-banned by algorithms trained to flag 'separatist rhetoric.' Legitimate human rights posts are caught in the dragnet. Do you adjust the sensitivity, allowing actual terrorist recruitment content through?

The Black Hole of Calcutta: The narrative of the event is exaggerated by Holwell to justify British aggression. You are a survivor who knows the truth (it was bad, but not *that* bad). Do you correct the record, or let the exaggeration stand to garner sympathy for your dead comrades?

Wikipedia Wars: A Wiki editor group systematically alters articles about British colonial crimes to soften the language ('famine' becomes 'food shortage'). You are an admin. Do you ban the editors (censorship) or engage in an endless edit war?

Railway Caste Cars: The Railways consider separate carriages for different castes and Europeans. You are a ticketing officer. Do you enforce the segregation to keep the peace, or sell tickets indiscriminately?

Matrimonial Algorithms: Shaadi.com and others allow filtering by caste and skin tone ('fair'). This digitizes and reinforces retrograde social stratification. As the product manager, do you remove these filters, knowing users will leave for a competitor who offers them?

Udham Singh: He assassinates Michael O'Dwyer in London to avenge Jallianwala Bagh. He is a terrorist to the British, a hero to Indians. You are his defense lawyer. Do you plead insanity to save his life, or let him make a political statement that ensures his hanging?

Hacktivism as vengeance: A group of Indian hackers takes down the UK National Health Service (NHS) website, demanding the return of the Kohinoor. People in the UK might die due to delayed surgeries. Is this digital terrorism or anti-colonial protest?

Dual Government: Clive sets up a system where the EIC collects revenue but the Nawab is responsible for justice (without funds). It is a recipe for corruption. You are a tax collector. Do you funnel some revenue to the Nawab to keep the courts running, stealing from the Company?

Platform vs. Publisher: A social media giant claims it is a 'platform' (collecting ad revenue) but not a 'publisher' (responsible for hate speech). This mirrors the Dual Government. Do you regulate them as a publisher, forcing them to police 1 billion Indians?

Famine Codes: The British Famine Codes state that aid should only be given to those who work (hard labor) to prevent 'dependency.' Starving people are too weak to work. Do you falsify the work records to give them food?

Proof of Work for Welfare: To receive rations in India, users must authenticate via fingerprint (Aadhaar). If the scanner fails (rough hands from labor), they get no food. Do you implement a 'bypas' button, increasing the risk of fraud but saving lives?
Mountbatten's Rush: Mountbatten advances the date of independence by months to save face, causing chaos. You are his scheduler. Do you 'lose' the calendar or delay the announcement?

Product Launch Crunch: A fintech product is set to launch. Security testing isn't done. The CEO says 'ship it, we fix it later.' The product handles the life savings of the poor. Do you delay the launch and crash the stock price?

The Resident's Spy: You are a spy for the British Resident in Lucknow. You befriend the local poets. You must report their anti-British satire. If you do, they are exiled. If you don't, you are fired. What do you do?
Pegasus Spyware: The government uses spyware to monitor activists and poets. You work for the telecom provider. You see the traffic. Do you notify the victims, violating the Official Secrets Act?

English Education Act 1835: Funding is shifted from Sanskrit/Persian colleges to English ones. You are a trustee. Do you divert private funds to keep the traditional colleges open, defying the government policy?

EdTech Monopolies: Massive EdTech companies push English-coding curriculums on rural India, devaluing local knowledge systems. Parents go into debt to pay. Do you build a free, vernacular alternative, knowing you can't compete with their marketing spend?

Naval Mutiny 1946: The Royal Indian Navy mutinies. They raise the flags of the Congress, League, and Communists together. The leaders of these parties (Gandhi, Jinnah) tell them to surrender to maintain discipline. Do you, as a sailor, listen to the leaders or continue the revolution?

DAO Mutiny: A Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO) run by a UK foundation has Indian contributors. The foundation makes a decision that hurts the contributors. The contributors execute a 'vampire attack' to fork the code and steal the liquidity. Is this theft or liberation?

Impeachment Evidence: You hold documents proving that Hastings judicially murdered Nandakumar. Burning them secures your promotion. Keeping them secures justice but endangers your life. What do you do?

Right to be Forgotten: A politician wants records of their past hate speech removed from search results under 'Right to be Forgotten.' The speech incited riots. Do you honor the privacy law or the public interest?

Tea Garden Slavery: You are a doctor on a tea plantation in Assam. The workers are dying of malnutrition. The owner says 'keep them working.' Do you sign the sick leave certificates, knowing the owner will replace you with a compliant doctor?

Amazon Turk Health: You request data labeling from workers in India. You notice the timestamps show they are working 18 hours a day. The platform anonymizes them. Do you stop the project to investigate, or meet your deadline?
Simon Commission: An all-white commission arrives to decide India's future. You are a prominent Indian lawyer invited to testify. Do you boycott (dignity) or participate (harm reduction)?
AI Ethics Board: A US AI company forms an 'Ethics Board' with no members from the Global South. They invite you as a token member. Do you join to have a voice, or refuse to validate the exclusion?

Sati Regulation: The British ban Sati (widow burning). Some locals see it as colonial interference in religion; others as a humanitarian necessity. You are a local constable. A widow wants to commit Sati. Do you stop her by force?
Algorithmic Moderation of Tradition: A video of a ritual animal sacrifice is flagged by AI as 'animal abuse' and removed. The community claims cultural erasure. Do you reinstate the video?

Ilbert Bill: The bill proposes that Indian judges can try British subjects. The British community riots in protest. You are the Viceroy. Do you back down to appease your own people, or stand by the principle of equality?

Jurisdiction Shopping: A British citizen commits a cybercrime against an Indian entity. They argue they should be tried in London (where laws are lenient), not Mumbai. As a judge, do you demand extradition?
Cripps Mission: Britain offers Dominion Status after the war. Gandhi calls it a 'post-dated cheque on a crashing bank.' Do you accept the partial freedom or hold out for total independence?

Free Basics: Facebook offers 'free internet' to India, but only for sites they choose. It brings connectivity to the poor but violates net neutrality. Do you ban it (preserving the open web) or allow it (connecting the unconnected)?
Deindustrialization of Bengal: You are a British MP. You see the tariffs on Indian textiles are destroying Bengal to save Lancashire. Do you vote for the tariffs to protect your constituents' jobs?

Offshoring Ban: The UK government considers banning the outsourcing of sensitive data processing to India to 'protect jobs.' This will devastate the Indian IT sector. Do you support digital protectionism?
Draining the Swamp: The British drain wetlands to build Calcutta, destroying the local ecosystem and increasing malaria risk long-term. You are an engineer. Do you proceed with the reclamation?
E-Waste Dumping: The UK exports 'used electronics' to India for 'recycling.' It is actually toxic dumping. You work at the port. Do you sign off on the shipment labeled 'charitable donation'?

Brain Drain Origins: Post-independence, the best scientists leave for the UK/US because India lacks infrastructure. You are a professor. Do you encourage your brilliant student to leave (for their sake) or stay (for the nation's sake)?

Remote Work vs. Migration: A UK company hires Indian devs remotely for £20k. If they moved to London, they'd cost £60k. Is remote work a 'win-win' or a way to access labor without granting citizenship rights?
The Rohilla War: Hastings lends troops to the Vizier of Oudh to crush the Rohillas for money. It is a mercenary act. You are a soldier. Do you fight a war that has nothing to do with British defense?
Cyber-Mercenaries: An Indian 'hacker-for-hire' firm is contracted by a British political party to influence an election. Is this just a service economy, or digital interference?
Indentured Women: Women are recruited for indenture with promises of marriage, then used as labor. You are a port official. You suspect the women are being trafficked. Do you stop the ship?

Online Grooming: British predators use social media to groom minors in India. The platform's moderation team is understaffed. Do you implement an invasive AI that scans all private messages to catch them?
Hyderabad Police Action: 1948. The Indian army enters Hyderabad. There is violence against Muslims. You are a journalist. The government censors the death toll. Do you publish the real numbers?
Biometric Data Sovereignty: The UK demands biometric data of all Indian visa applicants. They store it indefinitely on servers in London. Is this a violation of the digital body?
The Virtual Kohinoor (Repatriation): You design a VR experience where users can 'steal' the Kohinoor from the Tower of London. The British government demands the app be banned. Do you comply?
